message:
Timeouts often don't make sense for  higher-level socket code. Timeouts (and other forms of cancellation) are a best-effort attempt and may leave the socket in an unknown or invalid state (e.g., a partially-complete handshake). At which point the whole socket has to be torn down anyway and re-established before trying again.

If the API had a built-in timeout parameter, it wouldn't be clear that the socket may or may not be usable after timeout, and MS would be fielding questions about that a lot. Forcing users to close the socket to effect a timeout is a pit of success.
